_exec_summary.SummaryText:
KING COUNTY
DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES & PARKS (DNRP)
WASTEWATER TREATMENT DIVISION (WTD)
WEST POINT TREATMENT PLANT (WPTP)
EPA RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (RMP) and PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT (PSM) PROGRAM

Executive Summary
King County's West Point Treatment Plant (WPTP) at Seattle, Washington is subject to the requirements stated in Section 112r of the Clean Air Act and 40 CFR Part 68, Chemical Prevention Provisions, known as the Risk Management Program (RMP).  This executive summary and program submittal describes and details the key elements of WPTP Risk Management Program (RMP), as well as the associated Process Safety Management (PSM) program elements. This document also summarizes our existing health and safety programs; our internal management implementation procedures; and ongoing actions that are designed to prevent, eliminate or minimize the impacts of accidental releases of digester gas to the environment. The WPTP is proud of its continuous dedication and commitment to ensuring accident prevention, employee safety and process safety, and as a result the WPTP has had an excellent record in preventing accidents from occurring.
In demonstration of the WPTP's commitment to eliminate or minimize the impacts of potential accidental releases, as of August 2014, the WPTP has formally discontinued the use of chlorine gas for the disinfection of treated wastewater and has fully decommissioned the facility, equipment, and documentation associated with the storage and use of liquid chlorine.  As a result, the WPTP has converted to the use of sodium hypochlorite for the disinfection of wastewater. Formal deregistration of the chlorine gas disinfection system was certified by February 2015.

(1)Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy:
The WPTP is totally dedicated and committed to ensuring the prevention of any potential for accidental releases of toxic and flammables materials. The WPTP accidental release prevention program involves a unified ap

proach that integrates proven technology, state of the art equipment, advanced safety training programs, staff training on operation and maintenance practices, project management protocols and tested management system practices. All applicable procedures of the State of Washington Department of Labor & Industries, Department of Ecology and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as employee training, safety systems management, and emergency response procedures.  The WPTP is proud of its continuous dedication and commitment to ensuring employee and process safety, and as a result the WPTP has had an excellent record in preventing accidents from occurring.
As a result, the WPTP comprehensively complies with the EPA Risk Management Program under Section 112 (r) of the Clean Air Act (CAA) Amendments of 1990, 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68, and the State of Washington Department of Labor & Industries - Division of Occupational Safety and Health - Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals Program under Washington Administrative Code (WAC) 296-67.

(2)Description of Facility and Regulated Substances:
The WPTP is an integrated, advanced sewage treatment facility that provides both primary and secondary treatment of combined sewer system conveying and treating domestic and industrial wastewater, and storm water prior to discharge to Puget Sound. The site takes in combined wastewater and storm water from 21 conveyance pump stations and regulator stations in Seattle, north King County, parts of south Snohomish County, and areas east of Lake Washington.  The WPTP is located on the Puget Sound at the western tip of Discovery Park between Shilshole Bay and Elliott Bay. Currently, the WPTP can provide secondary treatment for flows up to 300 MGD and provides primary treatment and disinfection for flows exceeding 300 MGD. The plants maximum designed hydraulic capacity is 440 MGD. The We

st Point WWTP is rated as a US-EPA and WA-DOE Class IV treatment plant.
The liquid treatment process includes screening, grit removal, primary clarification, biological treatment using high rate oxygenated activated sludge, secondary clarification, sodium hypochlorite disinfection, and sodium bisulfite de-chlorination. The disinfected effluent discharges to Puget Sound through a multi-port diffuser located about 3,600 feet offshore. 
As for solids treatment, the primary and waste activated solids are blended in a tank and co-thickened via gravity belt thickeners. The thickened sludge is anaerobically digested in a system of digesters and dewatered by centrifuges. The plant produces biosolids used in agriculture and forestry, reclaimed water used for in-plant processes and irrigation. Digester gas (methane) is also produced, and this gas is used onsite to fuel the raw sewage pump engines, power cogeneration system, and supplies heat to the plant systems.
The facility complies with all applicable regulations and good engineering practices in the operation of two processes that have a greater than threshold quantity of hazardous chemicals as defined in the RMP requirements. These processes are the wastewater digester gas (methane flammable mixture) system and the propane fuel tank system.  
It is the policy of King County to meet and/or exceed all applicable federal, state, and local laws in the operation of all processes, and to design and operate the systems in accordance with the best industry standards to protect workers, visitors, and the public. 
The WPTP digester gas was previously considered a system that was eligible for the exclusive fuel exemption, as the digester gas is used exclusively as a fuel for onsite processes. However, a joint assessment and interpretation ruling by EPA Region 10 and the State of Washington Department of Labor & Industries, interpreted that the digester gas system's recirculation of digester gas through the digesters is considered a

n additional  "process use" and therefore is not eligible for exemption from the RMP regulation. The propane storage tank system is utilized in 100% capacity as a back-up fuel system and is therefore technically considered exempt under the provisions of the exclusive fuel use exemption.
(3) The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:
The general accidental release prevention program includes the following key program elements;
a)	Risk Management Plan - comprehensive plan for preventing the accidental release of hazardous chemicals.
b)	WPTP PSM/ RMP Program Manual -  comprehensive manual to centralize safety information and better ensure existing program elements are being properly implemented at the site. 
c)	PSM/ RMP Management System - system designed to provide and ensure the consistent implementation of the PSM/RMP program.
d)	PSM/RMP Management Committee and Sub-Committees the PSM/RMP Management Committee and sub-committees of specific subject matter experts, which meets monthly and/or weekly as needed, to comprehensively address all aspects of the implementation of the PSM/RMP Program
e)	PSM/ RMP Hazard Assessment - program designed to ensure the review and analysis of potential worst-case scenarios, alternate-case scenarios, and five year accident history.
f)	WTD Employee Safety & Accident Prevention Program - comprehensive program implementing all Safety Management Systems elements directing Safe Work Programs, Policies, Procedures and Training.
g)	Process Safety Information - information pertaining to the process is accurate and up to date.
h)	Process Hazards Analysis - formal technical hazard reviews are conducted and updated.
i)	Operating Procedures - written standard operating procedures are in place and up to date.
j)	Maintenance Procedures - written preventive maintenance procedures are in place and up to date.
k)	Training - personnel are formally trained for the technical and safety aspects of the jobs th

ey are to perform.
l)	Mechanical Integrity - written procedures are in place for inspection, testing and maintenance of equipment.
m)	Management of Change - procedures are in place to review and approve changes to the process.
n)	Pre-Startup Review - a formal procedure is in place to review changes to the process before startup.
o)	Compliance Audits - periodic comprehensive reviews of the PSM/ RMP elements for compliance.
p)	Incident Investigation - incidents with the potential for serious consequences are reviewed by a dedicated team.
q)	Employee Participation - all employees are required to participate in all of the release prevention program elements.
r)	Safe Work Practices (Hot Work Permit) - special permits, protocols, procedures and programs are in place for all Hot Work, Hazardous Energy Control, Electrical Safety, Confined Space Entry and Gas Purging operations.
s)	Contractor Safety - a formal program is in place for the selection and review of contractors.
t)	Emergency Planning, Response & Recovery - program to ensure the establishment and implementation of the necessary emergency action plans for various potential emergency scenarios

In the event of an accidental PSM/ RMP release, the WPTP is well practiced and exercised in the implementation of the WPTP emergency action plans, as well as the notification and coordination with the City of Seattle Fire Department, King County Zone 5 Technical Response Teams, the King County Office of Emergency Management and other applicable emergency response agencies.

Chemical-specific prevention steps include staff awareness of the hazardous properties of digester gas, the presence of methane detectors, alarms, beacons, pressure relief devices, flame arrestors, Ovation Supervisory Control System and the other redundant safety control systems.
The WPTP accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:
a)	Commitment to safety by the Wastewater Treatment Division and WPTP management and staff
b

)	Comprehensive process safety information and technical system information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors
c)	Comprehensive corrective and preventive maintenance program
d)	Routine shift checklist and process hazard analysis of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review
e)	Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment
f)	Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with operations and maintenance staff participation
g)	High level of training of operators and maintenance staff
h)	Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, and auditing programs by highly qualified and experienced staff
i)	Comprehensive oversight by the PSM/RMP Management Committee and Sub-Committees of specific subject matter experts to address all aspects of the implementation of the PSM/RMP Program
(4) Five-Year Accident History:
The West Point Treatment Plant (WPTP) has completed the required updated 5-year accident history review and has not had a reportable accident in the last five years that involved deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations or sheltering in place. Procedures and policies are in place and implemented to properly report, respond, record, investigate and debrief any such future accidents and/or incidents.  As a result, the WPTP RMP/ PSM Program has maintained an exemplary safety record with no significant accidental releases of regulated substances. Minor equipment incidents and equipment maintenance issues have been promptly addressed with thorough investigations and corrective measures to prevent recurrence.

(5)WPTP Emergency Response Plan/ Emergency Action Program:
The WPTP emergency response plan and emergency action program has continually evolved and has been routinely updated from successful existing programs to assure worker safety at the facility. It is the policy of the King County Department of Natural Resources and Park

s, Wastewater Treatment Division to notify the King County Office of Emergency Management and Seattle Fire Department Technical Response teams and request that they respond to various emergency conditions at the facility. This policy has been discussed, coordinated, implemented and exercised with the fire department and they are aware of the specific chemicals that exceed threshold quantities.  
(6)Planned Changes to Improve Safety:
The WPTP is constantly striving develop and implement workplace safety improvements for employees, contractors, collection, conveyance and treatment processes, as well as our surrounding community neighbors. Through the continuous implementation of the PSM/ RMP Program, the WPTP routinely reviews and pursues process and program changes to improve the safety of the regulated systems, and the facility as a whole.  The current safety improvement projects at the WPTP include the following: 
a)	Continued expansion, development and training of the principles of PSM/ RMP to the current regulated PSM/RMP Systems utilizing the AIChE Center for Chemical Process Safety 
b)	Expansion and development of the principles of PSM/ RMP to other unregulated wastewater hydraulic system through the new WTD Wastewater Hydraulic Life Safety Management (LSM) Program.
c)	Database updating and formal migration of the legacy MainSaver Computerized Maintenance Management System (CMMS) to an updated MAXIMO CMMS with integrated PSM/ RMP Program elements 
d)	Expansion of the WTD Safety & Hazardous Materials Program to include new Safety & Emergency staff positions allowing for increased PSM/RMP time allocation for the WPTP - Plant Safety Officer.
e)	Continued development of an onsite Safety, Emergency & Technical Training capabilities and staff resources
f)	Enhanced staff and physical security protocols, barriers, video monitoring systems,  key card access security, and other Physical Security Elements as identified in the ASCE Guidelines for Critical Infrastructure Se

curity for Wastewater Facilities
g)	Upgraded SQL database programming of digital photo enhanced Safe Work Procedures (SWP) including a specific emphasis on Hazardous Energy Control Procedures (HECPs), Confined Space Entry Procedures, Chemical Safety Procedures and PSM/RMP Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs).
h)	Enhanced annual review and update of the WPTP PSM/ RMP Program Manual and the associated employee training 
i)	Enhanced annual review and update of the WPTP Emergency Response Plan and the associated employee training
j)	Enhanced training and response exercise drills with the City of Seattle Fire Department Technical Response Teams, King County Office of Emergency Management, and King County Zone 5 Hazardous Material Response. 
k)	Enhanced update and revision of WPTP Operations and Maintenance (O&M) Manuals, O&M Training and the associated employee safety emergency response training
In Conclusion
King County's West Point Treatment Plant (WPTP) demonstrates unwavering commitment to the highest standards of safety, operational integrity, and regulatory compliance, as evidenced by its comprehensive Risk Management Program (RMP) and associated Process Safety Management (PSM) elements. Through robust accidental release prevention and emergency response protocols, meticulous handling of regulated substances, and continuous safety enhancements, the WPTP ensures the protection of its employees, the community, and the environment.
The WPTPs exemplary five-year accident history, proactive emergency response strategies, and recent transition to safer chemical alternatives underscore its dedication to mitigating risks and enhancing safety. Moving forward, the WPTP remains focused on implementing advanced safety measures, upgrading critical equipment, and fostering a culture of continuous improvement to safeguard against accidental releases and uphold the integrity of its operations.
By adhering to these principles and practices, the WPTP not only meets but exceeds regu
latory requirements, setting a benchmark for excellence in process safety management and environmental protection.
